ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained a greater understanding of modern Hebrew, and improved my sight reading of academic material
reading modern academic Hebrew faster and more accurately, tool to look for and understand words and phrases I am unfamiliar with
I learned how to translate the overall meaning of a sentence rather than word for word. I think this skill will benefit me in future language courses.
I developed the ability to read modern Hebrew and built on my biblical Hebrew grammar skills. I also built my Hebrew vocabulary and learned some spoken Hebrew as well.
I learned to read and translate modern academic Hebrew, and I came away from the course feeling I am able to do so very well, with knowledge of the appropriate resources.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: practical skills, organized teaching style, a variety of teaching media, interesting and engaging classes

Weaknesses: could use more language theory/practice, more focus on vocabulary, and more/smaller assignments

lots of homework which was time-consuming and did not always feel relevant

very involved professor, very helpful and understanding

I really liked that every student got the chance to work on an academic article they found interesting. We weren't stuck translating easy sentences from a grammar book, but got to read academic Hebrew right away. It did feel like a lot of work sometimes. Some of it I understood and other things I didn't. For instance, highlighting the same words in the Hebrew and English form of our abstracts for the final felt a little futile. The tests also seemed like they covered a lot of information. Perhaps weekly quizzes with less to study and memorize for would have been better.

I really enjoyed the article translation and the in-class translations and exercises. In the future, I would spend class time on articles worked on collectively by the class and assign just the individual articles for homework.

This course was very good at teaching us how to translate modern academic Hebrew and introducing us to important resources. Different methods of translation (word-by-word and skimming/scanning) were taught, and while I had issues adapting to the skimming and scanning, I feel like the class taught word-by-word translation very well. The workload was very high, and I think the amount of text we had to translate for each class was at times too much and difficult to keep up with.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I might recommend this course to another student, but only if they have some familiarity with modern Hebrew (even a month of Duolingo lessons). Because I had only biblical Hebrew, and no modern, I struggled with grammar and syntax.
Yes, I learned useful skills that I will be able to use later on in my academic career.
For someone interested in learning how to read an academic article in MH over the course of a semester, I would definitely recommend this class to them.
Absolutely. Prof. Roginsky is an excellent teacher and I learned a lot from the course.

I would definitely recommend this course to students who know biblical Hebrew and need to learn how to translate modern academic Hebrew for their academic and professional development, especially if they are in biblical studies.
